awd_titl_txt: INFEWS/T2: The sustainability-productivity tradeoff: Water supply vulnerabilities and adaptation opportunities in California?s coupled agricultural and energy sectors
awd_abstract_narration:
The interdependence of water availability, agricultural production, and electric power generation is well established, yet significant challenges remain for understanding how decisions or resource disruptions in any one of these sectors impact the system as a whole. Nowhere is this challenge more pressing than California, which, despite chronic water scarcity, continues to lead the nation in agricultural production by a factor of two. In California, nonstationary climate is expected to increase the frequency and severity of drought, with highly uncertain impacts on the availability of surface water. The subsequent effects on statewide electricity generation and agriculture in California's Central Valley will be closely linked. Surface water availability in the Valley is largely driven by snowmelt from the Sierra Nevada, which is stored and distributed to irrigation districts for food production.  During drought, however, irrigators must pump groundwater to compensate for scarce surface water. As a result, electricity demand from groundwater pumping rises by up to 33%, primarily during summer months when urban electricity demands also peak. Reduced runoff during drought also translates to less hydro-power generation (which accounts for ~20% of California's capacity), forcing electric utilities to rely on more expensive natural gas generation. The combination of higher electricity demand and increased reliance on natural gas leads to higher electricity prices. Thus water scarcity drives irrigators to pump significantly more groundwater when electricity prices are highest, an activity that becomes still more expensive if groundwater levels continue their historical decline. These issues illustrate the coupled challenges facing California's food-energy-water (FEW) systems, encompassing multiple scales of governance, from statewide planning and management of infrastructure to local irrigation district and farm-level decisions.

The overarching contribution of this research is the design and integration of an open source modeling- simulation framework for the California FEW systems (CalFEW), with interactive visualization, sensitivity analysis, and multi-objective optimization tools to discover key vulnerabilities and tradeoffs across sectors. This new decision support framework will achieve four major scientific objectives. First, it will determine the impacts of climate change-induced variability on the amount, timing, and location of precipitation and runoff in the Sierra Nevada range. Second, this knowledge will be integrated into CalFEW to improve understanding of how the coupled systems will respond to future shocks in the form of water scarcity, commodity price dynamics and regulatory change. Third, it will leverage CalFEW to develop a suite of novel tools for reducing supply/financial risk and incentivizing more sustainable water-electricity consumption in the agriculture sector.  Finally, the project will design and test portfolios of risk management tools to balance near-term productivity and long-term robustness/resilience across sectors and spatial scales. All tasks will rely on collaboration with a diverse group of decision-makers to understand how their perspectives on future risks, candidate policy actions, and preferred measures of system performance will affect the adoption of new, more coordinated management approaches.

por.por_cntn:
The interdependence of water availability, agricultural production, and electric power generation has become increasingly clear, yet outstanding questions remain unanswered regarding how decisions, extreme weather (e.g., drought) and resource disruptions in any one sector impact the system as a whole. In California, snowpack fuels hydropower production and provides water for irrigation to the Central Valley (the most agriculturally productive area in the U.S.), making this region vulnerable to hydrologic drought. During drought, irrigators pump groundwater to compensate for scarce surface water, increasing electricity demand, while at the same time reduced hydropower generation is replaced by more expensive natural gas generation, increasing electricity prices precisely when farmers? groundwater pumping is highest. It remains a fundamental challenge to understand how these drought feedbacks and their associated financial risks impact decisions at the farm scale, particularly regarding irreversible capital investment in perennial crops (e.g., nut and fruit orchards) an individual decision that carries significant implications for regional water resources sustainability. Furthermore, meeting future demands in California, and the rest of the American West, will require massive investments in water-related infrastructure over the coming decades. These investments that must be directed with a focus on more than just the greatest aggregate benefit, and include considerations of equity across communities and investment partners, with special attention to underrepresented groups. Meeting all these challenges requires first modeling the physical and financial/economic connections across multiple sectors, then simulating the stochastic dynamics of the flows of water, energy and money at decision-relevant temporal and spatial scales. A second major hurdle is representing the behavior of key human institutions (e.g., irrigation districts, groundwater banks, and electric utilities), who either absorb drought-related financial shocks or transfer them to end users (growers, underrepresented communities) via price changes. The third challenge is how to incorporate deeply uncertain future states of the world that cannot be described probabilistically, including climate change as well as other exogenous uncertainties from regulatory and technological change (e.g., groundwater pumping limits, renewable energy expansion). The highly interdisciplinary research conducted in this project made significant contributions to the development of improved modeling of food-energy-water systems, while also generating a host of new insights that suggest that there are many opportunities for improving the management of these complex systems.

This research project developed a host of products (e.g., peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, computer models, dissertations), as well as a number of compelling insights that were communicated beyond academic circles to government agencies, stakeholders and the American public (via mainstream media).  With respect to publication, this project has generated 41 publications in high profile peer-reviewed journals (e.g., Environmental Research Letters, Water Resources Research, Advances in Water Resources, Applied Energy, Earth?s Future, Environmental Justice) to date, with another 5 articles in press/review and many more in preparation. Consistent with NSF?s focus on ?Convergence?, the vast majority of these publications included interdisciplinary groups of co-authors from across the natural sciences, engineering and the social sciences. Three large-scale, open-source, interdisciplinary computer modeling platforms were developed, including the California and West Coast Power Systems model (CAPOW), the California Food-Energy-Water Systems (CALFEWS) model and the Operation of Reservoirs in California (ORCA) model. All three modeling platforms are currently being used by researchers outside of the project team, including other academicians, government agencies (U.S. Department of Energy) and other stakeholders. This project also supported seven graduate students (4 Ph.D./3 M.S.) through to completion of their degree, with another four graduate students in process (3 Ph.D./1 M.S.), while also allowing for the professional development of six post-doctoral researchers. It is important to note that the insights generated via this research were sufficiently compelling that they attracted the attention of numerous mainstream media outlets.  These included National Public Radio (twice), NBC Learn, NSF Office of Public Affairs, The Los Angeles Times, CCTV?s Global Business America, The Guardian (UK), Wired Magazine, and The Weather Channel, as well as numerous smaller outlets such as podcasts (e.g., Waterloop), local media (e.g., Chapelboro Radio), online news services (e.g., Circle of Blue) and other virtual outlets (YouTube: La Hora de la Verdad (The Hour of Truth)). One of the primary goals of this project was to meet NSF?s definition of ?Translational? research, consequently, the research team communicated directly with practitioners across the state of California throughout the project.  This group included irrigation districts (e.g., Rosedale Rio Bravo, Delano-Earlimart, Arvin-Edison), power utilities (e.g., San Francisco Public Utilities Commission, Pacific Gas & Electric), state agencies (e.g., California Department of Water Resources, California Department of Food and Agriculture) and non-governmental actors (e.g., Public Policy Institute of California). The two-way flow of information developed through these relationships proved valuable to both the research team and the stakeholders, providing numerous opportunities for improving the research products while also allowing for the dissemination of research results to groups in a position to make direct use of them.
